key_points: The Darkside ransomware gang accessed Colonial Pipeline using a compromised password for an inactive VPN account without multifactor authentication.
The attack on April 29 led Colonial to shut down its 5,500-mile natural gas pipeline for five days, affecting over 10,000 gas stations.
The compromised VPN password was found on the dark web, suggesting a Colonial employee reused a password that had been hacked elsewhere.
There's no evidence of phishing or other attacker activity before April 29 related to the compromised credentials.
Colonial discovered a ransom note on May 7, prompting the closure of the pipeline, which supplies 45% of the East Coast's fuel.
Colonial Pipeline CEO Joseph Blount decided to pay a $4.4 million ransom in Bitcoin to receive a decryption tool.
Mandiant was brought in to investigate the breach and has found no evidence of subsequent attempts to access Colonial's network.
Investigators tracked the hackers' movements but found no indication they breached critical operational technology systems.
Colonial has hired cybersecurity experts John Strand and Rob Lee to consult on cyber defense post-attack.
Charles Carmakal (SVP and CTO of FireEye's Mandiant division) and Joseph Blount (CEO of Colonial Pipeline) were primary sources, confirmed by FireEye and Colonial spokespeople.
spokespersons: Charles Carmakal (SVP and CTO, FireEye's Mandiant division)
